Like group III-V materials, which have obviously broadened the scope of group IV family and enriched the semiconducting members, a lightest representative of group II−IV−V2 family, BeCN2 monolayer, as an isoelectronic counterpart to group III-V semiconductor has for long remained unsolved for its applications in HER/OER/ORR, although previous first-principles investigations have touched the configuration and existence toward multiple crystalline forms of BeCN2. Using density functional theory calculations, the stable BeCN2 monolayer is predicted to be a direct bandgap semiconductor with high ultraviolet light absorption, achieving photocatalytic overall water-splitting within full pH, whose photogenerated electrons/holes will provide an external potential to obviously reduce the overpotential of HER and even make it achieve a spontaneous OER within pH 0–14. Meanwhile, it presents significantly anisotropic and high carrier mobilities (104 order) with preferred electron/hole transport along the x/y-direction, providing rich and required charge sources for HER/OER/ORR. After TM-decoration, the catalytic activities are greatly enhanced, achieved by the low HER and OER/ORR overpotentials of 0.05/0.07 V for V/Co@BeCN2 and 0.79/0.43 V for Ni@BeCN2, respectively. Plus, under pH 0–14, the OER overpotential of Ni@BeCN2 can be completely overcome by the external potential provided by photogenerated holes, achieving bifunctional catalysis for OER and ORR. Particularly, the Ni-d orbital is evidently hybridized with the O-p orbital for OH*Ni@BeCN2, so that the initial lone electrons located at the anti-bonding orbital pair up can populate the downward bonding orbital, allowing the species *OH to be moderately adsorbed on Ni@BeCN2, and thus redound the performance of OER/ORR. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords First-principles calculations Photocatalytic water splitting Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nowadays, the ever-increasing energy crisis and global environmental challenges, the excessive consumption of non-renewable tradition energy to meet global energy requirements is giving rise to sacrifice of fossil fuels and CO2 emission at an alarming rate leads to worldwide greenhouse effect, are two severe issues we are facing, and the technologies that can manufacture green energy without environmentally harmful products at its combustion end are sought after [1–3]. Against this pressing background, high-performance and cost-effective photo-/electrocatalysts are imperative [4], which play critical roles in the storage and conversion of renewable energy, such as proton exchange membrane fuel cells, rechargeable metal-air batteries, and hydrogen production from water-splitting[5], including oxygen evolution/reduction reaction (OER/ORR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) mechanisms [6–8]. However, since the multi-step proton-coupled-electron transfer is involved during oxygen electrode reactions, the OER and ORR with scale relationships usually suffer from a sluggish kinetic rate and high overpotentials, limiting the overall efficiency of energy conversion and storage [9,10]. Up to now, the highly sought-after catalysts are still dominated by noble-metal-based materials, such as Pt for HER and ORR, IrO2/RuO2 for OER [11,12]. However, the reserve scarcity and high cost of these noble-metal-based catalysts make widespread and industrial scale applications daunting. Such that, it is of great necessity and consequence to design low-cost and efficient catalysts that can alleviate current predicament and energy problems [9,13]. Honda-Fujishima's pioneering work about TiO2 for photocatalytic water splitting has opened the prospect of semiconductor photocatalytic technology for applications in energy conversion and storage [14]. Unfortunately, the high recombination rate of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and low utilization of solar energy result in an unsatisfying photocatalytic efficiency, limiting large-scale applications. As yet, two-dimensional (2D) semiconductors have been widely explored for the purpose of photocatalytic water splitting and bifunctional OER/ORR on account of low recombination of photoexcited carriers, large surface area, short carrier migration distance, massive active sites, tunable bandgap, and good optical adsorption, like AlAs [15], BiP3 [16], and ε-SnS [17]. Currently, enormous attention has been paid to transition metal nitrides, sulfides, and phosphides for their potential applications in photocatalysis, the vast majority of which present high catalytic activity and desirable carrier mobility, such as GeSe/GeS, MXenes, and group-IV monochalcogenides ultra-thin sheets have been deemed as promising catalysts [18–20]. Moreover, it has been widely accepted that MoS2, a species of transition metal sulfides, is an outstanding HER catalyst [21], whereas its weak dispersion for band edges due to relatively localized d-orbital leads to large effective carrier masses and hence poor electron transport, limiting its further catalytic applications. Subsequently, another direct band gap semiconductor, black phosphorene has high carrier mobility [22], but extremely easy degeneration in air makes it difficult to be used in catalysis. Interestingly, graphene-like carbon-based material and its derivatives have gained enormous attention benefiting from large carrier mobility and ultra-high stability. As a key member of graphene-like derivatives, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is an easy-to-synthesize and low-cost 2D material, has been utilized for the photocatalytic hydrogen production [23]. Besides, naturally evenly distributed large pores on g-C3N4 can offer rich and uniform nitrogen coordination sites with electron-rich lone pairs for capturing transition metal (TM) atoms to form TM@g-C3N4 single-atom catalysts (SACs), such as Niu et al. [24] reported that Pd@g-C3N4 stands out with a low ORR overpotential of 0.46 V. Another star member of the graphene derivatives, the high stability and purity BN touches upon several lattice phases including the cubic (c-BN), wurtzite (w-BN), and graphitic (g-BN) phases [25–27], of which rich physical and chemical performances highlight outstanding multifunctional applications of BN for nonlinear optics, ferroelectricity, piezoelectricity, and even super-hard materials [28,29]. However, wide band gaps of BN limit their applications in catalysis. As such, Yang et al. [30] designed a semi-hydrogenated graphitic BN monolayer, a strip-like antiferromagnetic semiconductor, which can be served as a visible-light driven photocatalyst for water splitting. Going beyond the structure of BN, as intermediates of graphene and BN, a recently predicted BCN compound possesses distinctive chemical and physical properties and even is suitable for photocatalytic water splitting on account of the ternary ingredients allowing higher tunable degrees of freedom [31]. Followed immediately, Luo et al. [32] designed the lightest members in the II-IV-V2 family, isoelectronic counterparts of BN, one of which is the phase of Pmc21, a monolayer of such graphitic BeCN2 displays charming potential in water-splitting. However, to our knowledge, a comprehensive and systematic catalytic insight for BeCN2 is missing, and even for it as a substrate to form SACs is also virgin. In the present work, to examine its potential applications in catalysis, we have systematically explored its stability, mechanical properties, electronic structures, carrier mobility, photocatalytic/electrocatalytic HER/OER/ORR using first-principles calculations. Our results demonstrate that the stable BeCN2 monolayer is a direct semiconductor with high ultraviolet light absorption suitable for photocatalytic water-splitting, achieving overall water-splitting within full pH. Particularly, the overpotential of HER will be significantly reduced and even achieving a spontaneous OER within pH 0–14 when BeCN2 is in a light environment. Plus, monolayer BeCN2 also exhibits significantly high carrier mobilities of the order of 104 cm2 V−1 s−1 with preferred electron/hole transport in the x/y-direction, providing sufficient charge sources for HER/OER/ORR. After TM-decoration, the HER, OER and ORR activities are greatly enhanced, achieved by the low HER and OER/ORR overpotentials of 0.05/0.07 V for V/Co@BeCN2 and 0.79/0.43 V for Ni@BeCN2, respectively. Particularly, the OER overpotential of Ni@BeCN2 can be completely overcome by the external potential supplied by photogenerated holes, achieving bifunctional catalysis for OER and ORR under pH 0–14. Finally, the origin of OER/ORR activity on TM@BeCN2 was also investigated with different descriptors ( Δ G O H * , ε d and ICOHP). 2 Computational method All first-principles calculations were carried out by using the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) based on spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) [33]. The generalized gradient approximation formulated by Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) was applied to characterize the exchange-correlation functional within the framework of projector-augmented-wave (PAW) theory [34]. To consider van der Waals (vdW) interactions, semiempirical D3 correction method, as recommended by Grimme et al. [35], was utilized. The integration over the Brillouin zone (BZ) was executed using the Monkhorst-Pack scheme for k-point sampling, a grid of 2 × 2 × 1. The plane wave unfolds with a cutoff energy of 500 eV, and the convergence criteria for energy and force are set to 10−5 eV and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. To avoid interactions between neighboring periodic images, a vacuum layer of ∼29 Å was applied along the direction perpendicular to the 2D plane. Partial Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (pCOHP) and its integrals can be directly obtained from plane wave data using the LOBSTER software package [32]. The computations for phonon spectra were conducted employing the PHONOPY software, which operates on the principles of density functional perturbation theory [36]. To assess thermodynamic stability, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations spanning 6 ps were performed, utilizing a time step of 1 fs [37]. To mitigate the potential underestimation of the band gap caused by the PBE functional, the Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE06) hybrid functional is employed to attain accurate band structures [17]. A quantitative assessment of charge transfer can be achieved through Bader charge analysis [38]. Supercells, composed of a 3 × 3 × 1 primitive cell, were employed to construct transition metal (TM)-anchored slabs, forming single-atom catalysts. More details on the calculations of HER, OER and ORR are provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and stability of BeCN2 Considering that all constituted atoms in sp2-monatomic-thick motifs of group III-V monolayers are 3-fold coordinated, several unknown allotropes could be topologically mapped onto the orthogonal lattice of group-IV monolayers (such as graphene) with eight atoms each primitive cell. A feasible and easy approach to create group II-IV-V2 monolayer that is isoelectronic to group III-V monolayers is to simultaneously occupy the four group III sites using two group II and two group IV elements. Following this strategy, we used the group III-V compound featured with a form of cubic B4N4 (cubic BN) monolayer to construct the group II-IV-V2 monolayer, Be2C2N4 (BeCN2), i.e., replacing the four group III B atoms with two group II Be atoms and two group IV C atoms. This isoelectronic counterpart of cubic BN monolayer is packed into a 2D space group of Pmc21 (No. 26) with orthogonal lattice, as shown in Fig. 1a, the π − π overlaps in which are well-preserved compared with graphene and cubic BN, resulting in forming a sp2-monatomic-thick planar configuration. The well-optimized lattice parameters of BeCN2 are a → = 4.34 Å and b → = 5.25 Å and α = β = γ = 90 ° , where the bond lengths between Be/C and N atoms are in the range of 1.57–1.64/1.31–1.42 Å, and the bond angles correspond to the range of 106.56°-132.80° (see Table 1). Each element is tri-atomically coordinated, herein, N for Be and C atoms is the sole coordination element, while the N atoms possess a locale coordination moiety of Be2C or C2Be. To understand the bonding features of Be-N and C-N, the electron localization function (ELF) analysis was carried out, which is a position-dependent function ranging from 0 (ideal ionic bonds or van der Waals interactions) to 1 (ideal covalent bond or lone pair electrons) [39]. We noticed that large ELF values in regions corresponding to interatomic spacing of Be-N and C-N are significant, exhibiting that covalent dominated interactions between atoms in BeCN2 are formed, as shown in Fig. 1b. Then, differential charge density of BeCN2 monolayer was adopted to further elucidate its bonding nature. As obviously seen in Fig. 1c, there is a charge depletion on Be/C site and their contiguous hollow of the lattice, while the charge is accumulated and well delocalized predominantly over the bonding region between every two atoms, indicating that all constituted atoms form multicenter covalent bonds with adjacent other atoms. About the aforementioned covalent contributions, based on the pCOHP, the chemical-bonding analysis is performed, herein, all bonding states are located below the Fermi level corresponding to populated orbitals by electrons, while antibonding states are located above the Fermi level corresponding to non-populated states by electrons. As seen in Fig. 1d, the pCOHP of the Be-N and C-N bonds validates that no antibonding levels occur in the valence bonding region compared with the unoccupied conduction orbitals, the covalency is thus considerably pure. Meanwhile, values of integrated pCOHP (ICOHP) for C-N are significantly negative than those of Be-N, suggesting that C-atoms with high electronegativity induced stronger bonding strength and shorter bond length. Although BeCN2 presents rather interesting structural and bonding characteristics, we are still unclear whether it is a stable atomic motif. To obtain an effective evaluation for the stability of the BeCN2 monolayer, the cohesive energy of BeCN2 was firstly calculated according to the Eq. S(1) in Supporting Information and the value is − 6.01 eV/atom, as a reference, which is dramatically lower than those of theoretically predicted monolayers including δ-AlP3 (−3.59 eV/atom) [40], ε-SnO (−4.55 eV/atom) [41], α -CSe (- 3.86 eV/atom) [17] and δ-SnS (−3.84 eV/atom) [17], and even lower than those of experimentally realized phosphorene (−3.30 eV/atom) [22] and germanene (−3.24 eV/atom) [42], ensuring that monolayer BeCN2 is a stably connected network. The stability of BeCN2 could be further demonstrated by its AIMD simulation, thus, a AIMD simulation of 6 ps using a 3 × 3 × 1 supercell from 400 K (Fig. 1e) to 1400 K was performed to investigate the thermodynamic stability of BeCN2, where the atomic motif remains stable without obvious lattice distortion until 1300 K (Fig. S1). At 1400 K, however, the monolayer has a pronounced structural undulation, that is, the maximum temperature that the BeCN2 monolayer can maintain its structural stability is ∼1300 K. Then, the dynamic stability of BeCN2 was also assessed in terms of the phonon dispersion curves and phonon density of states of BeCN2 (see Fig. 1f-g), where no imaginary frequency in the whole momentum range is present, proving the high dynamic stability of BeCN2. Moreover, the highest phonon frequency reaches up to 1634.31 cm−1 at the Y point, which is significantly higher compared with those of δ-SnS (300 cm−1) [17], δ-AlP3 (442 cm−1) [40] and Si3P (540 cm−1) [43], suggesting robust bonding for Be-N and C-N bonds. Finally, the mechanic stability of BeCN2 was also evaluated by calculating the independent elastic constants, which were 214.87 N/m, 65.54 N/m, 218.73 N/m, 89.79 N/m for the components C 11 , C 12 , C 22 and C 66 , respectively. An inevitable requirement for the mechanic stability [44] is C 11 > 0 , C 11 C 22 > C 12 2 and C 66 > 0 , herein, it can be seen that the elastic constants of BeCN2 satisfy these requirements, indicating that BeCN2 has good mechanical stability. 3.2 Mechanical properties of BeCN2 To obtain the ideal tensile strength of BeCN2, starting with the well-relaxed BeCN2 monolayer, consecutive tensions are applied along either uniaxial x-direction or y-direction. Herein, the so-called ideal tensile strength denotes the highest bearable stress, the strain at which the ideal tensile strength obtains corresponds to critical strain. When a series of in-plane uniaxial strains from 0 to 0.26 along the x-direction/y-direction are imposed, the y-direction/x-direction lattice constant was fully relaxed and the strained lattice was fixed, meanwhile all atomic positions were also well-relaxed regardless of x-direction or y-direction strain. As shown in Fig. 2a, the stress induced by x-direction strain increases monotonically in the range of applied tensile strains from 0 to 0.12, then the stress decreases monotonically ranging from 0.12 to 0.26, that is, reaching its maximum value of 16.1 N/m at a critical strain of 0.12. Similarly, the stress induced by y-direction strain firstly increases then decreases monotonically, where a tensile strain of 0.15 is the inflection point of stress-strain curve, i.e., a maximum stress of 16.8 N/m at 0.15 is obtained. Interestingly, according to previous reports, the maximum stresses that BeCN2 can withstand in the x/y direction are much larger than those of BiP3 (2.46/2.17 N/m) [16], δ-SnS (3.31/2.5 N/m) [17] and α-CSe (4.008/10.96 N/m) [45], implying a large resistance to tensile strain. In order to investigate the response of the material to strain, the transverse response of BeCN2 induced by uniaxial tensile strain is described in Fig. 2b. We noted that when a tensile (compressive) strain is applied in the x-direction, the induced strain is negative (positive) along the y-direction and vice versa, exhibiting a positive Poisson effect. In Fig. 2b, the data are fitted to the cubic polynomial y = A x + B x 2 + C x 3 + D ,where v x y = - A = 0.30 and v y x = - A = 0.30 are the linear Poisson’s ratio. Considering a fact that the anisotropic geometric configuration usually induces a highly orientation-dependent mechanical property for BeCN2. To obtain a full understanding for the mechanical behavior of BeCN2, orientation-dependent Young's modulus E ( θ ) and Poisson's ratio v ( θ ) based on the results of elastic constants thus are calculated according to Eqs. S(2) and S(3). It was found that the E ( θ ) of BeCN2 increases steadily from a minimum value of 195.23 N/m along the x-direction to a maximum value of 219.57 N/m at about θ = 45 o (see Fig. 2c), implying obvious mechanical anisotropy. Clearly, the smaller Young's modulus of BeCN2 compared to those of other materials were found, such as graphene (342 N/m) [46], MoS2 (330 N/m) [47], and BN (318 N/m) [48], suggesting that the BeCN2 monolayer is highly flexible. As shown in Fig. 2(d), one can see that the values of v ( θ ) for the BeCN2 monolayer are also spatially varying, i.e., an angle-dependent positive Poisson’s ratio. The minimum and maximal values about Poisson’s ratio are 0.22 and ∼0.31 along the diagonal direction and the x/y-direction, respectively, catering to the fitting results in Fig. 2b. 3.3 Electronic properties of BeCN2 Having demonstrated the stability and discussed the mechanical properties of the BeCN2 monolayer, we turn our focus to the band structure, since it is a decisive and key factor for effective mass, carrier mobility, optic absorption and even photocatalytic water splitting. The electronic band structure demonstrates a semiconducting characteristic for BeCN2 with a direct band gap of 3.31 eV (2.22 eV), both the conduct band minimum (CBM) and the valence band maximum (VBM) being at the Y point, at the HSE06 (PBE) level, as presented in the Fig. 3a and S2. In projected band structure, the CBM shows the C and N atoms are responsible for a dominant contribution, while the VBM is primarily contributed by N atoms. Further detailed observation from the partial density of states (PDOS) indicates that the CBM is mainly contributed by the p z orbitals of the C atoms, with slight weight of the p z orbitals of the Be and N atoms, meanwhile the VBM is mainly contributed by the p z orbitals of the N atoms, and the contribution from the p z orbitals of other two atoms is quite tiny. These features match well with the calculated partial charge density at the CBM and VBM (see Fig. 3c and d), and the charge cloud of CBM and VBM from different atoms favor the reduction of recombination of photogenerated electron and hole pairs, i.e., the extended charge separation time results in the lifetime of the photogenerated carriers being increased, and the carrier’s application efficiency is thus expected to be enhanced. In this situation, bare C atoms could provide electrons to electron drawing adsorption species, such as oxygen-containing intermediates and hydrogen, and the N atoms can contribute empty orbitals to electron-donor adsorbates, therefore, BeCN2 is expected to balance the adsorption strength and exhibit good HER/OER/ORR performance. As seen in the projected band structure plotted in Fig. 3a, an obvious anisotropy under investigation is found, i.e., different effective masses of the carriers along different lattice directions may be presented. Intuitively, the CBM has a strong (weak) dispersion in the Γ − Y ( Γ − Y ) direction, while the band dispersion of the VBM is relatively flat in the Γ − X ( Γ − Y ) direction. Using the Eq. S(5) of Supporting Information to fit the band dispersion, and the effective masses of electrons and holes thus can be obtained, as summarized in Table 2. For electrons, the effective masses are predicted to be 0.782 m 0 and 0.285 m 0 along the Γ − X and Γ − Y directions, respectively, and calculated effective hole masses are 1.095 m 0 (0.814 m 0 ) along the Γ − X ( Γ − Y ) direction. Herein, it was found that the effective electron/hole mass of Γ − X direction is 2.744/1.345 times higher than that of the Γ − Y direction, corresponding to a dispersive CBM/VBM along the Γ − Y direction and relatively flat CBM/VBM along the Γ − X direction. These features imply that BeCN2 may exhibit obvious anisotropy for carrier mobility along the Γ − X and Γ − Y directions, especially for hole. To obtain a more intuitively understanding for the band dispersion near the CBM and VBM, 3D band valleys are plotted in Fig. 3(b), whereas for the insets, the band dispersions in the vicinity of the Γ point along the Γ − X (ka) and Γ − Y (kb) directions are displayed. We noticed that the CBM valley is significantly sharper than the VBM valley along the Γ − X / Γ − Y direction, matching well with the analysis of effective mass. 3.4 Small effective mass, ultrahigh carrier mobility, strong optical absorption Effective mass and mobility of carriers are two key factors to quantitatively evaluate the transfer capability of electron-hole pairs in water splitting or ORR along a certain direction, therefore, the direction-dependent carrier effective mass benefiting from anisotropic lattice was firstly investigated. Fig. 4a-b describe the direction-dependent effective masses of electrons and holes, from which we found that the effective electron and hole masses of BeCN2 are highly anisotropic with a “peanut” and “chubby egg” shape, respectively, owing to the dispersive p-orbitals of C/N predominantly contributing to the CBM/VBM. According to the values of effective carrier masses, the electron (hole) effective mass of BeCN2 is relatively small in the y-direction compared to that of other 2D materials such as: α-P ( m e = 1.13 m 0 , m h = 1.81 m 0 ) [49], monolayer KTlO ( m e = 0.74 m 0 , m h = 2.40 m 0 ) [50] and th-AlN ( m e = 0.79 m 0 ; m h = 5.60 m 0 ) [51]. The smaller carrier effective mass facilitates the transfer of carriers to the active site during reaction and improves the reaction efficiency. Meanwhile, the significant difference between the effective masses of electrons and holes is conducive to the electron-hole separation and reduction of electron-hole pairs recombination. Also, according to the deformation potential (DP) theory [52], which can be adjusted by acoustic phonon scattering through inter-valley and intra coupling, the carrier mobility of 2D ultrathin nanosheet can thus be estimated using the Eq. S(4) of Supporting Information. Herein, we used a small strain ranging from − 0.02 to 0.02 (see the strain schematic of Fig. 4c) to fit the values for elastic modulus and deformation potential, band edge position using vacuum energy level as reference and total energy against the isotropic strain along the x-direction and y-direction are plotted in Fig. 4d-e. As we can see, the linear fittings of the band edge positions and the parabolic fittings of total energies are perfectly presented, ensuring the reliability of the calculation. The coupling strength between the electron/hole and the acoustic phonon can be quantitatively described by the values of DP constants, meanwhile, we noticed that the DP constants with different directions listed in Table 2 are significantly different, regardless of electrons and holes, that is, there is a significant difference in such coupling strength. In other words, the scattering of electrons in the x-direction derived from the acoustic phonon is weaker than that of electrons along the y-direction, whereas, for the holes scattering derived from the acoustic phonon, the x-direction is considerably stronger than the y-direction. Considering that the DP constant takes a negative quadratic term in the determine relationship of carrier mobility, therefore, compared to other terms, a more significant impact for the carrier mobility stemming from the DP constant is imposed. The electron mobility of BeCN2 along the x/y-direction is predicted to be 1.19 × 10 4 / 0.74 × 10 4 cm 2 V − 1 s − 1 , and the mobility of holes is predicted to be 0.0412 × 10 4 / 8.16 × 10 4 cm 2 V − 1 s − 1 . Interestingly, although BeCN2 has smaller effective electron mass and larger in-plane stiffness along the y-direction compared with that of x-direction, the electron mobility along the x-direction is larger than that of y-direction. This phenomenon can be attributed to electron-acoustic-phonon interaction, where, for electrons, the weaker electron-acoustic-phonon interaction of x-direction in the BeCN2 monolayer causes an obviously smaller DP constant. Particularly, values of carrier mobility are significantly higher than that of many other 2D materials including silicon (1343 cm2 V−1 s−1) [53], δ-InP3 (2684 cm2 V−1 s−1) [54] and Pd4S3Se3 (564 cm2 V−1 s−1) [55], and MoS2 (200 cm2 V−1 s−1). Accordingly, the ultrahigh carrier mobility together with obvious anisotropy can sensibly diminish the recombination of electron–hole pairs, furthermore, they can speedily arrive to the reaction sites on BeCN2 to pitch in reaction, guaranteeing long-term catalytic activity. As we all know, during preparation process, the combination of mechanical loading and epitaxy on a substrate will inevitably lead to strain, that is, the electronic structure of BeCN2 is highly likely to be modulated by strain. A high strain capacity for BeCN2 has been demonstrated in Fig. 2, herein, uniaxial in-plane strains from − 0.05 to + 0.05 along the x-direction and y-direction were employed to investigate the strained band structure (see Fig. S3). We noticed that the band gap can be modulated monotonically from 3.312 eV to 3.533 eV with increasing tensions from 0 to + 0.05, while it first increases and then decreases mildly with an increasing compressive loading from 0 to − 0.05 (see Fig. 4f). Things are different for y-direction tensile and compressive strains, i.e., by applying increasing tensile loading from 0 to + 0.05, the bandgap of BeCN2 first increases and then decreases, yet the bandgap increases monotonically from 3.312 eV to 3.477 eV with increasing compressive strains from 0 to − 0.05 (see Fig. 4f). Interestingly, as seen in Fig. S3, regardless of the directions and size of the applied strain, the characteristic of direct bandgap is well-preserved, allowing convenient electronic transitions. To become a good photocatalyst, one must first become an excellent light absorber. Herein, two electric field polarizations along the x-direction and y-direction were considered, according to the Eq. S(8), in-plane light absorption coefficients of BeCN2 obtained by HSE06 were evaluated. As displayed in Fig. 5, the BeCN2 monolayer exhibits expectantly weak optical absorption regardless of strain, for which it is not difficult to imagine that it is caused by a big bandgap. In the ultraviolet region, the light absorption coefficient can reach the magnitude of 104 cm−1, where the unique atomic configuration of BeCN2 causes almost identical amount of in-plane light absorption along two lattice directions regardless of strain, exhibiting stable and strong light harvesting ability. In other words, the light absorption coefficients of BeCN2 would not be affected by strains, providing stable energy guarantee for photocatalytic water splitting. 3.5 Strain modulated band edge position and HER/OER driving force of bare BeCN2 As a desirable catalyst for photocatalytic water-splitting, in addition to possessing an appropriate bandgap (>1.23 eV), the energy positions of band edge must straddle the redox potential of water [56]. For strain-free BeCN2, in the full pH range, the band edges of CBM (−3.521 eV) and VBM (−6.833 eV) are higher than the reduction potential of H+/H2 and lower than the oxidation potential of O2/H2O (see Fig. 6a-b), respectively, suggesting that the BeCN2 monolayer can be served as a photocatalyst for overall water-splitting. As is well known, strain not only affects the band gap, but also the position of the band edge. That is, the band edge position will inevitably be modulated by strain, which will further affect the performance of photocatalytic water-splitting. Overall, uniaxial tensile/compressive strain of x-direction slightly lows/raises the energy position of VBM, while the opposite is true for y-direction strain. However, in contrast, compressive strains of x-direction and y-direction are more beneficial for HER. It should be noted that, at pH = 14, the CBM is lower than the reduction potential of H+/H2 when a tensile strain of 0.05 is applied in the y-direction, implying that the photocatalytic HER cannot occur under the condition of a tensile strain of 0.05. In a word, overall water-splitting in a wide pH range (0−13) almost remains valid, exhibiting a high-performance and little influence by pH. According to previous reports [17,57], the external potential provided by photoexcited electrons/holes for HER/OER ( U e / U h ) could be prescribed as the difference between CBM/VBM and reduction potential of H+/H2 in energy: U e = E C B M − ( − 4.44 + 0.059 * p H ) and U h = ( − 4.44 + 0.059 * p H ) − E V B M . Therefore, values of U e and U h for strain-free BeCN2 are both positive in pH 0–14, exhibiting that the overall water splitting on BeCN2 will be achieved from acidic, neutral, and even to alkaline conditions. Beyond that, for some cases, a photocatalyst that meets the conditions for photocatalytic water splitting may still suffer from high overpotentials of HER and OER. So, it is of our prime interest to gain an insight into individual half-cell reactions including HER and OER on BeCN2. As shown in Fig. S4, a 3 × 3 × 1 supercell was considered, six potential adsorption sites including the top of three atoms (N site (T1), Be site (T2), and C site (T3)), two bridge adsorption sites (N-Be bond (B1) and N-C bond (B2)), and one hole-centered adsorption site (H1) in six-membered ring were used to adsorb intermediates involved in the HER and OER processes. Conforming to assertions of Norskov and coworkers [58], a two-step/four-step reaction mechanism for water reduction/oxidation half-reaction is described in detail in Note S5 and plotted Fig. S5 of Supporting Information. All optimized geometries of HER and OER intermediates adsorbed on the surface of BeCN2 are plotted in Fig. S6, and free-energy profiles of different sites for HER and OER at different pH values are separately presented in Figs. S7-S18. As summarized in Table S1, values of HER and OER overpotential are large and unsatisfactory, meaning that, when the surface of BeCN2 in a dark environment, both half-reactions cannot proceed spontaneously. For HER, the adsorption of H* adsorbate is difficult, the Δ G H * increases with increasing pH value, similar to the case of equilibrium potential of H+/H2, and thus become its reaction barrier. When BeCN2 is in a light environment, photoexcited electrons will provide an U e as additional energy, which decreases as pH increases, significantly different from the case of Δ G H * . Herein, for HER, we utilized the case adopted the external potential ( U e = 0.92 V , cyan lines) to simulate the one in the light environment, as the cyan free-energy lines of four optimal sites (T1, T2, T3, and B1) presented in Fig. 6c-f. The value of Δ G H * was reduced in the light-added condition compared to the no-light condition, but its photocatalytic HER performance was still limited by the high overpotential, which resulted in a difficult photocatalytic HER process. On the other hand, in the dark environment, the OER also cannot proceed spontaneously at pH 0–14. Fortunately, when the BeCN2 monolayer receives light irradiation, photoexcited holes can provide an external potential ( U h ), which increases with raising pH, totally different from the case of Δ G (free-energy change) of OER intermediates. Obviously, at pH 1–14, all the elementary steps of OER are downhill (Figs. S13-S18), i.e., once irradiation is received, H2O molecules can be oxidized into O2 on the surface of BeCN2 spontaneously in mediums of full pH. 3.6 Structure and stability of TM@BeCN2 In recent years, it has been found in many studies that the catalytic activity can be effectively improved by doping transition metal atoms to form SACs and using the metal atoms as active sites correspondingly. Bhagat et al. [59] constructed a series of TM@g-C3N4 candidates by doping TM atoms in g-C3N4 and found that the Co@g-C3N4 exhibits a lower overpotential than that of pristine g-C3N4 in HER and OER. Zhao et al. [60] found that TM-doped A2X3 systems showed better HER catalytic activity, especially for Cu@As2Te3. These studies have inspired us to construct single atom catalysts through TM doping to reduce the overpotential of the primitive BeCN2 monolayer. As shown in Fig. 7a, a series of TM@BeCN2 SACs were constructed by using 23 transition metals to anchor on the Be-N double vacancy of BeCN2. The well-optimized lattice parameters of TM@BeCN2 are a → = 13.02 Å and b → = 15.75 Å , and the corresponding bond angles are α = β = γ = 90 ° . All optimized structures about TM@BeCN2 are plotted in Fig. S19-S22. To maintain a long-term catalytic activity and efficiency, the robust stability is an essential prerequisite. Herein, the stability of single TM atoms on the substrate was evaluated by calculating the binding energies (Eb) according to E b = E T M @ B e C N 2 – E T M – E V B e - N , where the E T M @ B e C N 2 , E T M , and E V B e - N represent the total energy of TM@BeCN2, the energy of an isolated TM atom, and the energy of a substrate with a Be-N double vacancy, respectively. The more negative the E b value, the tighter the bonding between the metal atoms and the substrate, as summarized in Table S2 and plotted Fig. 7b, the binding energies of all TM@BeCN2 are well below zero, ranging from − 2.83 to − 6.91 eV, indicating strong stability for TM@BeCN2. Bader charge analysis was utilized to determine the valence state of the TM atoms. The charge transfer from the TM atoms to the substrate leads to the TM atoms becoming positively charged, indicating a robust interaction between TM and substrate. Particularly, the trend of electronegativity is consistent with the decreasing amount of charge transfer from left to right for each period: Hf exhibits the lowest electronegativity of 1.30 and has a charge transfer amount of 1.40 e; in contrast, Au has a relatively high electronegativity of 2.40 corresponding to a low charge transfer amount of 0.03 e. Furthermore, the positive charge existing on the TM atoms makes TM-atom an ideal site for the adsorption of intermediates that contain oxygen, creating active center. 3.7 HER activity on TM@BeCN2 To evaluate the catalytic HER activity of the TM@BeCN2 catalysts, we first calculated the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption ( Δ G H * ) on TM@BeCN2 since the Δ G H * is considered as an efficient descriptor for HER activity [61]. All Δ G H * are summarized in Table S3, some of which are plotted in Fig. 8a. As is known to all, however, Δ G H * of a perfect HER catalyst should be close to 0[62]. Actually, catalysts with | Δ G H * | ≤ 0.09 eV are also deemed to possess high HER performance. For V and Co, the near-zero values of Δ G H * indicate that they could act as highly active HER sites, exhibiting an astonishing proximity to the ideal Δ G H * of 0 eV and even overmatching that of benchmark Pt (−0.09 eV) [63]. This striking performance unequivocally underscores the exceptional HER activity attaching to Co@BeCN2 and V@BeCN2, predicting their remarkable catalytic potential in sustainable energy conversion. The theoretical exchange current ( i 0 ) plays a paramount role in unraveling the underlying intrinsic electron transfer rate that governs the HER activity. A distinct and intriguing volcano-shaped curve is plotted to obtain an intuitive comparison for the HER performance of these as-designed TM@BeCN2 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 8b, where the exchange current at the volcano top is the most advantageous and thus corresponds to the best HER activity. According to Sabatier's principle, both too strong and too weak adsorption frustrates the HER activity. As exemplified by our findings, Ti@BeCN2 and Mo@BeCN2 exhibit their placement within the left branch of the volcano curve, indicating a pronounced affinity for H atoms and consequentially a more robust binding, which in turn leads to a comparatively sluggish release of hydrogen gas (H2). Conversely, catalysts like Ni@BeCN2 and Cu@BeCN2 are positioned on the right branch of the volcano, presenting a great challenge in binding of TM-atoms and H atoms. In such both cases, the corresponding i 0 are notably low, that is, a compelling inference emerges that the proximity of a catalyst to the summit of the volcano graph means an outstanding level of HER activity. Evidently, this assertion can be supported by a robust proof that two optimize catalysts including V@BeCN2 and Co@BeCN2 are conspicuously positioned at the acme of the volcano curve and possess the most positive exchange current. To explore the relationship between HER activity and Δ G H * more intuitively, HER overpotential ( η H E R ) was used to quantitatively describe the HER catalytic activity, and the relationship of η H E R with Δ G H * and H-adsorption energy ( Δ E H * ) is presented in Fig. 8c and d. Clearly, V@BeCN2 and Co@BeCN2 are located at the top/central region, confirming their optimal HER catalytic performance. 3.8 OER/ORR activity and activity trend of TM@BeCN2 OER and ORR activities are highly correlated with the adsorption of oxygenated intermediates (detailed adsorption free energy data of oxygenated adsorbates are summarized in Table S3), and the fully optimized adsorption configurations of intermediates are provided in Figs. S19-S22. Calculated overpotentials for OER/ORR ( η O E R / η O R R ) according to Eqs. S(17) and S(18) are listed in Table S2 and plotted in Fig. 9a. Among all candidates, Ni@BeCN2 has the lowest OER/ORR overpotentials of 0.79/0.43 V, followed by Co@BeCN2 with 0.94/1.05 V, corresponding OER/ORR free energy diagrams without illumination are given in Fig. 9b-c (other free energy diagrams can be found in Figs. S23-S25). The potential determine step (PDS) for both catalysts with the best catalytic OER activity is the formation of OOH * ( O * + H 2 O → O O H * + H + ) . For the ORR, which is the reverse reaction of the OER, the PDS for Ni@BeCN2 is also the formation of O O H * ( O 2 + H + → O O H * ), whereas the PDS for Co@BeCN2 is the desorption of OH * ( O H * + H + → H 2 O + * ). Considering that the OER overpotential can be overcome by the extra voltage supplied by the photogenerated holes, and the reaction would become spontaneous if the extra voltage is large enough. Next, taking Ni@BeCN2 with the best OER activity as an example, the band structure of Ni@BeCN2 was calculated by using the HSE06 method (see Fig. 9d) to estimate the voltage generated by the photogenerated holes. Calculated results indicate that the photoexcited holes can provided an external potential of U h = 3.194 V , which is much larger than the overpotential required (0.79 V) for the OER. When Ni@BeCN2 is in the light environment, all reaction steps become downward at pH 0–14 (see Fig. 9e and Fig. S26), i.e., the H2O molecules could be oxidized into O2 spontaneously in acidic, neutral, and even alkaline conditions. The catalytic OER properties of Ni@BeCN2 that can react spontaneously under light conditions are comparable to those of synthesized CoFe-LDH (0.28 V at 10 mA/cm2) [64] and FeSe2 (0.33 V at 10 mA/cm2) [65] experimentally. On the other hand, the CBM of Ni@BeCN2 is below the reduction potential, that is, it is impossible to obtain a driving force for photocatalytic HER. Also, the exciton binding energy (E eb) is computed to investigate the efficacy of carrier separation. The static dielectric constant (ε) is acquired using density-functional perturbation theory (DFPT) through the linear response method. The exciton binding energy and the exciton Bohr radius (a*) can be determined using the following formula, employing the hydrogenic model [66]: E eb = μ m 0 ε 2 R H , a * = m 0 μ ε a H where R H , m 0 and μ are the Rydberg constant of the hydrogen atom (13.6 eV), the free electron mass and the effective reduced mass, respectively. a H is the Bohr radius of the hydrogen atom. For the Ni@BeCN2 monolayer, E eb and a H were calculated to be 1.37 eV and 3.54 Å (see Table 3), respectively. In addition, the exciton binding energy of WS2 is 3.38 eV [67], while that of Ni@BeCN2 is much lower than that of WS2. These findings suggest that the exciton can be easily dissociated into free carriers. Our results indicate that Ni@BeCN2 monolayer, due to their high static permittivity and low exciton binding energy, could be served as a promising photocatalytic material. AIMD simulations of Ni@BeCN2 were carried out at 400 K. According to the results shown in Fig. S27, the total energy and temperature oscillate around the equilibrium state after 6 ps and the structure appears to remain unchanged, which suggests that the catalyst has a good thermodynamic stability for long-term use. Based on the above discussions, it was found that the overpotentials of the OER/ORR are closely related to the adsorption strength of intermediates. An obvious linear relationship exists between Δ G O * and Δ G O H * , as in Fig. S28, which can be described as Δ G O * = 1.83 Δ G O H * + 0.75 with a coefficient of determination of R 2 = 0.94 . Similarly, Δ G O O H * can be expressed using an expression of Δ G O O H * = 0.91 Δ G O H * + 3.14 (R2 = 0.93). We noticed that the square of correlation coefficient is basically equal for two equations, yet the scaling slope is obviously different, indicating that a different adsorption strength between oxygenated intermediates and TM atoms was existed. Specifically, a slope between Δ G O O H * and Δ G O H * of 0.91 indicates that the same TM-O single bonding for OOH* and OH* adsorbed on TM, whereas the slope between Δ G O * and Δ G O H * was 1.83, which is close to 2, implying a possible existence of TM = O double bonds between O* intermediate and TM atom. On the other hand, through such robust linear relationships described in Fig. S28, one can directly infer the overall catalytic performance using two independent variables: Δ G O H * and Δ G O * − Δ G O H * , instead of using complex multi-dimensions to understand the OER/ORR activity trend. Therefore, taking the 3d TM atoms including optimal Co and Ni as the object of study, the OER/ORR double volcano diagram was constructed based on a relationship of overpotential against the Δ G O H * and Δ G O * − Δ G O H * , as displayed in Fig. 10a. Clearly, in the dual volcano diagram, each TM@BeCN2 is located exactly on the volcano surface, indicating a good correlation between the two independent descriptors and corresponding overpotential. The closer the catalyst is to the top of the volcano, the better the activity. Fig. 10b-c shows the contour plots of the projected volcano map on the X-Y plane, where catalysts closer to the peak of the volcano in the dual volcano plot are likewise closer to the center of the volcano contour plots, which consist of four regions corresponding to four electron steps of the OER/ORR. For OER, the optimal catalytic activity at Δ G 2 = Δ G 3 , Ni@BeCN2 and Co@BeCN2 are close to the volcanic peak with respect to other TM@BeCN2 candidates, indicating good catalytic activity. Similarly, in the ORR volcanic contour plot (Fig. 10c), the best ORR activity is achieved when Δ G 1 = Δ G 4 . Herein, Ni@BeCN2 possesses a low ORR overpotential of 0.43 eV, which is clearly closer to the volcano peak compared with other catalysts, and its catalytic activity surpasses that of commonly utilized IrO2 (0.45 V) [68]. When we are searching for OER and ORR catalysts with good catalytic activity, what is their HER activities? To obtain an intuitive comparison, all overpotentials for the HER, OER, and ORR are plotted in Fig. 10d, where the TM@BeCN2 catalyst located in the bottom/front/left shaded area has good HER/OER/ORR catalytic activity. Although none of all the TM@BeCN2 catalysts can be seen as eligible multifunctional catalysts, the V@BeCN2 ( η H E R = 0.05 V) and Co@BeCN2 ( η H E R = 0.07 V) are excellent single functional HER catalysts, meanwhile, the Ni@BeCN2 ( η O E R = 0 V and η O R R = 0.43 V) under illumination can be identified as efficient bifunctional OER/ORR catalysts. 3.9 Activity origin of TM@BeCN2 To shed more light on the origin of activity and on how to enhance the activity of TM@BeCN2, d band center ( ε d ) of TM atoms is explored. The ε d can be served as an effective descriptor for evaluating the binding strength between reactants and different catalysts. Herein, for specific analysis, we choose 3d TM atoms containing optimal Ni and Co as the object of study. The ε d of TM@BeCN2 can be calculated according to the following equation [24]: ε d = ∫ − ∞ E f E ρ d ( E ) d E ∫ − ∞ E f ρ d ( E ) d E where the E and ρ d represent the energy band width of the d-orbitals and the density of states projected onto TM-d orbitals, respectively. As shown in Fig. 11a, Ti, V, and Cr atoms with less d electrons have a relatively positive value for the ε d (0.03 eV, 0.32 eV, and 0.21 eV, respectively), whereas, with increased d-electron occupation, the d-band centers gradually become more negative, e.g., from − 1.22 eV of Mn to − 2.12 eV of Cu. Consequently, a lower ε d would cause weaker adsorption for adsorbates adsorbed onto TM atoms, matching well with the results that Δ G O H * , Δ G O * and Δ G O O H * show negative correlations against the d-band center (see Fig. 11b). Interestingly, Δ G O * is more sensitive to the ε d compared to Δ G O O H * and Δ G O H * , so that the PDSs are Δ G 2 / Δ G 6 or Δ G 3 / Δ G 7 associated with Δ G O * for OER/ORR. Meanwhile, the nice linear relationship also proves that the ε d can be used as a good descriptor to characterize the catalytic activity. The upper (lower) panel of Fig. 11c presents the relationship between the required potential of each step ( Δ G ) and ε d in OER (ORR), which can provide a direct guide about how to enhance the catalytic performance and design efficient catalysts. For metal atoms with higher ε d ( > - 0.83 e V ), such as Ti (0.03 eV) and V (0.32 eV), the PDS of the OER reaction is the fourth step (OOH* → O2) due to strong O2-adsorption, causing that the entire OER process will be limited by difficult O2-desorption. On the contrary, for Fe (−1.11 eV) and Cu (−2.12 eV) with lower ε d ( < - 0.83 e V ), the weak adsorption of intermediates on TM leads to the formation of the adsorption species O* being difficult, and the PDS is thus the second step (OH* → O*). There is no doubt that, for the two circumstances, a high overpotential is inevitable. That is, a moderate ε d (−0.83 eV), at which the adsorption strength between the intermediates and TM atoms is neither too strong nor too weak, will make the catalyst have good OER catalytic activity. For example, Ni ( ε d = −1.04 eV) is the closest to − 0.83 eV among TM@BeCN2 and possesses an optimal OER overpotential of 0.79 V. To its credit, the same is true for ORR, i.e., the Ni@BeCN2 obtains a lowest ORR overpotential ( η O R R = 0.43 V) since its ε d is closest to the − 0.83 eV, at which the binding strength is neither too weak nor too strong. Therefore, the scheme as-built above provide us an innovative approach, i.e., modulating the ε d to an optimal level, to enhance the OER/ORR activity and design SACs more efficient. All above analyses proved that the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates has a great influence on the catalytic activity. To further understand the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates during OER/ORR, the charge density difference distribution of oxygen-containing intermediates was analyzed using Ni@BeCN2 as an example ( Fig. 12a). It can be clearly seen that there is a conspicuous charge exchange between the oxygen-containing intermediates and the TM atoms, implying that a chemical adsorption can be achieved by the TM-O bond. When oxygenated adsorbates are adsorbed onto TM atoms, new bonding and antibonding states occur, and the bonding strength between TM-O can be quantified by the ICOHP, where the more negative ICOHP, the stronger the TM-O bonding. As shown in Fig. 12b, due to similar bonding strength, the results also provide a reasonable explanation for the high linear correlation between Δ G O H * and Δ G O O H * . Meanwhile, the O* is found to be relatively stronger, the OER (ORR) thus needs more energy to desorb O* (adsorb OH* and OOH*), the PDS is usually Δ G 2 ( Δ G 5 / Δ G 8 ) step. A good linear relationship between the ICOHP and Δ G of different oxygen-containing adsorbates was achieved, suggesting that the adsorption strength related to the catalytic activity can be characterized by ICOHP. As mentioned above, Δ G O H * can be used a descriptor that can reasonably predict the catalytic OER/ORR performance, the PDOS and the pCOHP of Ni@BeCN2 were calculated (see Fig. 12d) to further reveal the origin of adsorption strength, meanwhile, that of Co@BeCN2 was also provided for a comparison (see Fig. 12e). Clearly, the d orbitals of the TM atoms and the p orbitals of the O atom in OH* undergo an obvious hybridization, forming new bonding and antibonding states. For the OH* adsorbed on Co@BeCN2, the value of the ICOHP (−2.72) between Co-O is relatively more negative, which results in OH* poisoning, while the ICOHP (−2.00) for Ni-O presents a moderate adsorption strength for OH* adsorbed on Ni@BeCN2. In Ni@BeCN2, the d-orbitals of Ni atom and the p-orbitals of O atom in OH* hybridize each other in the energy range of − 4.5 to − 1.7 eV, forming bonding contributions, and the hybridization in the energy range of − 1.6–0.5 eV dominates anti-bonding contributions (see Fig. 12f). Such hybridization makes the Ni-d orbital move down and occupy the bonding state and reduce the original Ni-d orbital on the antibonding state, promoting a suitable adsorption of OH* onto Ni. Three lone electrons of Ni-d orbital and a lone electron of the O-p orbital in OH* are well matched into two pairs of electron pairs, as shown in Fig. 12g, causing that the π-orbitals in the vicinity of the Fermi level obtain electrons and move down, so that the OH* can be appropriately adsorbed on Ni, promoting the catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions To summarize, using atomic transmutation based on first-principles calculations, we have identified a novel group II-IV-V2 monolayer as an isoelectronic counterpart to cubic BN monolayer in analogy to 2D group III-V materials, realized by monolayer BeCN2, which has dramatically broadened the scope of group V monolayers. The BeCN2 achieves high cohesive energy of − 6.01 eV/atom, high melting points (∼1300 K), absent imaginary phonon frequencies, and elastic constants meeting the Born-Huang stability criteria. A low Young’s modulus of 195.23 N/m∼219.57 N/m and a small Poisson’s ratio of 0.22–0.31 were found, confirming relatively low stiffness and high flexibility. Monolayer BeCN2 exhibits significantly high carrier mobilities of the order of 104 cm2 V−1 s−1 with preferred electron/hole transport in the x/y-direction. It has a direct bandgap with high ultraviolet light absorption suitable for photocatalytic water-splitting, achieving overall water-splitting within full pH. Calculated overpotentials of HER/OER on six possible adsorption sites are large of bare BeCN2, however, when BeCN2 is located in a light environment, the photogenerated electrons/holes will provide an external potential to obviously reduce the overpotential of HER and even achieve spontaneous OER within full pH. After TM-decoration for BeCN2, the HER activity is greatly enhanced, achieved by the HER overpotentials of 0.05 V for V@BeCN2 and 0.07 V for Co@BeCN2. In addition, the Ni@BeCN2 SACs possesses the best catalytic OER/ORR performance with an overpotential of 0.79/0.43 V, whose OER overpotential can be completely overcome by the external potential supplied by photogenerated holes, achieving bifunctional catalysis for OER and ORR under pH 0–14. The origin of OER/ORR activity on TM@BeCN2 was investigated with different descriptors ( Δ G O H * , ε d , ICOHP). Particularly, the Ni-d orbital is evidently hybridized with the O-p orbital for OH*Ni@BeCN2, so that the initial lone electrons located at the anti-bonding orbital pair up can populate the downward bonding orbital, allowing the species *OH to be moderately adsorbed on Ni@BeCN2, and redound the performance of OER/ORR. coredata.dc:description: Like group III-V materials, which have obviously broadened the scope of group IV family and enriched the semiconducting members, a lightest representative of group II−IV−V2 family, BeCN2 monolayer, as an isoelectronic counterpart to group III-V semiconductor has for long remained unsolved for its applications in HER/OER/ORR, although previous first-principles investigations have touched the configuration and existence toward multiple crystalline forms of BeCN2. Using density functional theory calculations, the stable BeCN2 monolayer is predicted to be a direct bandgap semiconductor with high ultraviolet light absorption, achieving photocatalytic overall water-splitting within full pH, whose photogenerated electrons/holes will provide an external potential to obviously reduce the overpotential of HER and even make it achieve a spontaneous OER within pH 0–14. Meanwhile, it presents significantly anisotropic and high carrier mobilities (104 order) with preferred electron/hole transport along the x/y-direction, providing rich and required charge sources for HER/OER/ORR. After TM-decoration, the catalytic activities are greatly enhanced, achieved by the low HER and OER/ORR overpotentials of 0.05/0.07 V for V/Co@BeCN2 and 0.79/0.43 V for Ni@BeCN2, respectively. Plus, under pH 0–14, the OER overpotential of Ni@BeCN2 can be completely overcome by the external potential provided by photogenerated holes, achieving bifunctional catalysis for OER and ORR. Particularly, the Ni-d orbital is evidently hybridized with the O-p orbital for OH*Ni@BeCN2, so that the initial lone electrons located at the anti-bonding orbital pair up can populate the downward bonding orbital, allowing the species *OH to be moderately adsorbed on Ni@BeCN2, and thus redound the performance of OER/ORR.
coredata.dc:title: Designing an isoelectronic counterpart to group III-V semiconductors: A novel honeycomb BeCN2 monolayer with ultra-high mobility toward solar driven overall water splitting and bifunctional oxygen evolution/reduction reaction
